Disney on Vacation
Vocabulary activity
University of Auckland

The Reading Activity will primarily be used to check a learner's comprehension of a given text. This can be done by asking the learner to reflect on the reading and respond to questions about the reading, or by having them complete some other possibly more physical task based on the reading.

Teachers should keep the following in mind when using this iDevice:

  1. Think about the number of different types of activity planned for your resource that will be visually signalled in the content. Avoid using too many different types or classification of activities otherwise learner may become confused. Usually three or four different types are more than adequate for a teaching resource.
  2. From a visual design perspective, avoid having two iDevices immediately following each other without any text in between. If this is required, rather collapse two questions or events into one iDevice.
  3. Think about activities where the perceived benefit of doing the activity outweighs the time and effort it will take to complete the activity.
Enter the details of the reading including reference details. The referencing style used will depend on the preference of your faculty or department.
What to read

Hello and welcome!

This is an A1 vocabulary activity to learn the different things that you can do on vacation and how to express them.

Let's get started!

Survey
Describe the tasks related to the reading learners should undertake. This helps demonstrate relevance for learners.
Use feedback to provide a summary of the points covered in the reading, or as a starting point for further analysis of the reading by posing a question or providing a statement to begin a debate.
What are you going to learn?

What to read

This is a vocabulary activity for A1 level in which you will name and identify the different activities that you can do during vacation, in order to express them correctly in spoken and written English. You are going to practice with different exercises, combining grammar information and vocabulary.
Describe the tasks related to the reading learners should undertake. This helps demonstrate relevance for learners.
Use feedback to provide a summary of the points covered in the reading, or as a starting point for further analysis of the reading by posing a question or providing a statement to begin a debate.
What do I need?
Do you remember the Simple Past?

What to read

For this activity you need to know the past simple.

We use the past simple to express actions that started and finished in the past. This is very useful to talk about vacation activities, as they are past events. 

If you have some problems with vocabulary,

you will see this online dictionary on each section.

You can remember the structure with this PDF.
Describe the tasks related to the reading learners should undertake. This helps demonstrate relevance for learners.
Use feedback to provide a summary of the points covered in the reading, or as a starting point for further analysis of the reading by posing a question or providing a statement to begin a debate.
Summer Activities
Summer vacations are the best!

What to read

Summer is traditionally associated with hot weather  and rain . 

Schools and universities usually have a summer break (or summer vacation).

People like to do outdoor activities, for example going to the beach, playing sports or camping. Also it is a good oportunity for students to work and earn some money. 

Let's see the most common summer activities.

  • camping
  • kayaking
  • sightseeing
  • snorkeling
  • sunbathing
  • swimming
  • boating
  • hiking
  • fishing
  • traveling
  • barbecuing
  • playing sports
  • bicycling
  • picnicking
  • working

 Make two lists; in the first one, write the words that you know (or the ones that are similar to your language). In the other one, write the unknown words and their meaning to create a glossary. Follow this example:
Describe the tasks related to the reading learners should undertake. This helps demonstrate relevance for learners.

II. Hit "enter" to submit your answers and check the feedbak.

 If your answer is incorrect, check the words that you don't know and add them to your glossary.

True/false questions present a statement where the learner must decide if the statement is true. This type of question works well for factual information and information that lends itself to either/or responses.
Type the question stem. The question should be clear and unambiguous. Avoid negative premises as these can tend to be ambiguous.
Escriba la pregunta. La pregunta debe ser clara y no ambigua. Evite las premisas negativas ya que esta tienden a ser ambiguas.
Mickey, Donald and Goofy went fishing in this picture.

Introduzca la retroalimentación que quiere que vean los estudiantes después de haber intentado completar la actividad. Este campo se puede dejar vacío. Si este campo está vacío se ofrecerá la retroalimentación por defecto.
False! They went camping.
Se puede proporcionar una pista para ayudar al estudiante a responder la pregunta.
Escriba la pregunta. La pregunta debe ser clara y no ambigua. Evite las premisas negativas ya que esta tienden a ser ambiguas.
Goofy went snorkeling.

Introduzca la retroalimentación que quiere que vean los estudiantes después de haber intentado completar la actividad. Este campo se puede dejar vacío. Si este campo está vacío se ofrecerá la retroalimentación por defecto.
That's true! He was wearing a snorkel =
Se puede proporcionar una pista para ayudar al estudiante a responder la pregunta.
Escriba la pregunta. La pregunta debe ser clara y no ambigua. Evite las premisas negativas ya que esta tienden a ser ambiguas.
Mickey enjoyed sunbathing during his vacation.

Introduzca la retroalimentación que quiere que vean los estudiantes después de haber intentado completar la actividad. Este campo se puede dejar vacío. Si este campo está vacío se ofrecerá la retroalimentación por defecto.
True! In summer we can enjoy sun
Se puede proporcionar una pista para ayudar al estudiante a responder la pregunta.
Escriba la pregunta. La pregunta debe ser clara y no ambigua. Evite las premisas negativas ya que esta tienden a ser ambiguas.
Max and Goofy went hiking.

Introduzca la retroalimentación que quiere que vean los estudiantes después de haber intentado completar la actividad. Este campo se puede dejar vacío. Si este campo está vacío se ofrecerá la retroalimentación por defecto.
False! They didn't go hiking, they went fishing.
Se puede proporcionar una pista para ayudar al estudiante a responder la pregunta.
Escriba la pregunta. La pregunta debe ser clara y no ambigua. Evite las premisas negativas ya que esta tienden a ser ambiguas.
Mickey and his friends did some sightseeing.

Introduzca la retroalimentación que quiere que vean los estudiantes después de haber intentado completar la actividad. Este campo se puede dejar vacío. Si este campo está vacío se ofrecerá la retroalimentación por defecto.
True! When you do sightseeing, you visit interesting places like a tourist.
Se puede proporcionar una pista para ayudar al estudiante a responder la pregunta.

If this option is set, each word will be marked as the learner types it rather than all the words being marked the end of the exercise.

Enter the text for the cloze activity in to the cloze field by either pasting text from another source or by typing text directly into the field.

To select words to hide, double click on the word to select it and click on the Hide/Show Word button below.

More than one possible answer can be defined enclosing them with pipes (|). I.e.: |dog|cat|bird|

If left unchecked a small number of spelling and capitalization errors will be accepted. If checked only an exact match in spelling and capitalization will be accepted.

For example: If the correct answer is Elephant then both elephant and Eliphant will be judged "close enough" by the algorithm as it only has one letter wrong, even if "Check Capitalization" is on.

If capitalization checking is off in the above example, the lowercase e will not be considered a mistake and eliphant will also be accepted.

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

hiking
kayaking
sightseeing
boating
swimming
barbecuing

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!
Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.
Winter Holidays
What can you do in winter?
University of Auckland

What to read

Winter is the coldest season of the year.

  Schools and universities have a winter break (or winter     holidays).

 Generally, holidays are the days to celebrate or commemorate a tradition of cultural or religious significance.

    In winters, there is usually snow and ice , so you can do this activities outside:

    • go snowboarding
    • ice skating
    • go skiing
    • make a snowman

    But, what if it is too cold outside and you want to stay warm at home? These are some indoor activities that you probably do in winter.

    • watching a movie
    • a TV series marathon
    • reading a book
    • playing board games
    • playing videogames
Describe the tasks related to the reading learners should undertake. This helps demonstrate relevance for learners.
Use feedback to provide a summary of the points covered in the reading, or as a starting point for further analysis of the reading by posing a question or providing a statement to begin a debate.
A winter experience.
Provide instruction on how the cloze activity should be completed. Default text will be entered if there are no changes to this field.

I. Complete the story with the past simple form of these verbs.

be(x2) - cook - give - play - skate - spend - read - watch - snow

II. Click on "send" to check your answers.
University of Auckland
If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

My winter break.

My last winter break was amazing. First, I spent the first cold days in the house with my family. We played some board games such as Monopoly. I cooked some cookies with my grandma and then I watched the eight Harry Potter movies. 

The last days were even better. It snowed day and night so next day we made a snowman in the backyard. My parents gave me my first roller skates so I skated on ice. Finally, I read a science fiction book. It was a very intesresting story.
If this option is set, each word will be marked as the learner types it rather than all the words being marked the end of the exercise.

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!

1. You can do outdoor activities at home.

False. Outdoor refers to open-air activities (outside).

2. Christmas is an example of Holiday.

Introduzca la retroalimentación que quiere que vean los estudiantes después de haber intentado completar la actividad. Este campo se puede dejar vacío. Si este campo está vacío se ofrecerá la retroalimentación por defecto.
True. Holidays can have a religious meaning.
Se puede proporcionar una pista para ayudar al estudiante a responder la pregunta.
Escriba la pregunta. La pregunta debe ser clara y no ambigua. Evite las premisas negativas ya que esta tienden a ser ambiguas.
3. Reading a book is considered and indoor activity.

Introduzca la retroalimentación que quiere que vean los estudiantes después de haber intentado completar la actividad. Este campo se puede dejar vacío. Si este campo está vacío se ofrecerá la retroalimentación por defecto.
True. Indoor refers to interior activities.
Se puede proporcionar una pista para ayudar al estudiante a responder la pregunta.
Escriba la pregunta. La pregunta debe ser clara y no ambigua. Evite las premisas negativas ya que esta tienden a ser ambiguas.
4. Students cannot have a winter break because they must go to school and college.

Introduzca la retroalimentación que quiere que vean los estudiantes después de haber intentado completar la actividad. Este campo se puede dejar vacío. Si este campo está vacío se ofrecerá la retroalimentación por defecto.
False. Schools and universities grant a winter vacation every year.

Reading Activity
University of Auckland

The Reading Activity will primarily be used to check a learner's comprehension of a given text. This can be done by asking the learner to reflect on the reading and respond to questions about the reading, or by having them complete some other possibly more physical task based on the reading.

Teachers should keep the following in mind when using this iDevice:

  1. Think about the number of different types of activity planned for your resource that will be visually signalled in the content. Avoid using too many different types or classification of activities otherwise learner may become confused. Usually three or four different types are more than adequate for a teaching resource.
  2. From a visual design perspective, avoid having two iDevices immediately following each other without any text in between. If this is required, rather collapse two questions or events into one iDevice.
  3. Think about activities where the perceived benefit of doing the activity outweighs the time and effort it will take to complete the activity.
Enter the details of the reading including reference details. The referencing style used will depend on the preference of your faculty or department.
What to read

Now let's see how to express what we did on vacation.

Pay attention to the following rules.

How was your vacation?

  • For a period, use vacation (singular) - vacationS is wrong-.

I always go on vacation in July. 

  • Use ON with vacation -  IN vacation is wrong-.

For questions, use:

  • Where to mention the place. 

Where did you go? -I went to Chiapas.

  • When to mention the date or period. 

When did you visit London? - I visited London last year.

  • Who to say the people you were with. 

Who did you go with? -I went with my family.
Describe the tasks related to the reading learners should undertake. This helps demonstrate relevance for learners.
Use feedback to provide a summary of the points covered in the reading, or as a starting point for further analysis of the reading by posing a question or providing a statement to begin a debate.
Cloze Activity
Provide instruction on how the cloze activity should be completed. Default text will be entered if there are no changes to this field.

I. Complete the conversation between Daisy and Minnie with the correct word.

did   - arrived - sightseeing - when - on - made - traveled - summer
University of Auckland
If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

- Hey Minnie! What did you do on your last vacation?

- Last vacation I  traveled  with Mickey and Pluto.

- Where did you go?

- I spent my vacation at the beach. We went to Cancun.

- What did you do there?

- We arrived at the beach at 8:00 AM, we immediately went swimming into the sea. Then we made some sandwiches for lunch. After lunch, we did some sightseeing .

- Great! When did you go? 

- We went in the summer break.
If this option is set, each word will be marked as the learner types it rather than all the words being marked the end of the exercise.

- We went in the summer break.

- Great!

did you go?

break.

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!

The majority of a learning resource will be establishing context, delivering instructions and providing general information. This provides the framework within which the learning activities are built and delivered.
Use this field to enter text. This iDevice has no emphasis applied although limited formatting can be applied to text through the text editing buttons associated with the field.
Free Text

Vacation is over!

 It's time to go back to school 

Now you are ready to use this vocabuary.

Let's practice what you learned today. 

  • Write a short text describing your last vacation or your favorite vacation from your childhood.
  • Check that you use the correct past form of the verbs.
  • Use the vocabulary that you learned today.
  • If you don't know how to say a word, use the online dictionary.

Did you like this activity?

  • Write a short personal reflection in your notebook about this activity. Use sentences similar to:

I liked that... I learned that... It is difficult to... The activity is funny/boring/interesting...

  • Create a glossary with all the new words you learned in this activity.

      2. In order not to lose points, it is important to check not only your answer but your spelling too.
